title: What will be Saudi Arabia's crude oil production for October 2019, according to OPEC?
possible_answers: More than 8,000 tb/d and less than 9,000 tb/d
preds:
Very close to highest threshold at 9,90
https://www.euronews.com/2019/10/31/opec-october-oil-output-jumps-on-swift-saudi-recovery-reuters-survey
OPEC MOMR Oct 2019 issue reports Saudi production at 8,564 (Table 5-9). Saudi officials expect full restoration by end of November. Hence, I re-allocated 5% from 9+ mbd to 8-9 mbd.
Adjusted to high side. Possible SA tops 10000.

They have ability to (fairly easily) slightly exceed 10. They may go for it - expect it to be close. In their best interest to “drill baby drill” in light of IPO and retain market share. Potentially lower increases in USA shale production too...per second article expect close to 9.9 in Oct and Nov
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-research-crude-goldman/goldman-sachs-lowers-forecast-2020-us-shale-oil-output-growth-idUSKBN1X10V7
https://oilprice.com/Latest-Energy-News/World-News/When-Will-Saudi-Oil-Production-Return-To-Pre-Attack-Levels.html
Production in Sept was ~8.5 so I think they end up around where they where in the 9-10 range for this month
There is a small chance of a strike similar to that of sept.16th that could knock 10 to 20% of production.

Gah.  
The crowd is too high forcing me higher -(

Saudis claiming 9.86M/day for October and November even though capacity is higher.  Suppressing due to agreed upon output cuts along with OPEC.  Revising downward.  Source: https://www.reuters.com/article/us-oil-opec-russia-discussions/saudi-oil-output-seen-above-pre-attack-levels-in-october-november-idUSKBN1WT0UJ

OPEC Website. (2019). Monthly Oil Market Report - October 2019. Retrieved from
https://momr.opec.org/pdf-download/ Table 5 - 9: OPEC crude oil production based on secondary sources, tb/d
8,564 - September page 58  Noting back to normal after the Iranian attacks now.

Saudi Aramco forecasting 9 900 for October. Wondering if they will try to exceed given IPO?
https://www.cnbc.com/2019/10/09/saudi-aramco-says-full-oil-production-capacity-will-return-by-end-nov.html

There was a big spike in oil price after the attack. Now, oil prices are lower than before the attack. It is important to bear in mind the strategic incentive SA has in "catching up" to the annual production goal.

Their production in September shows that towards the end of the month they were able to get back on track for +10M levels.  Leaving room for further potential strikes that disrupt.  Claims for full productivity capability (12M/day) appear trustworthy at this point.  They will want to replenish their reserves.

News that Saudi Aramco says full oil production will return by "end of November" makes me believe that production will most likely not exceed 10 mb/d. Also note that production was around 8.5 mb/d in latest September data pull. I expect by end of October for oil production to be in between 9-10 mb/d

Production doesn't generally decrease in "standard" years. Production was back to 8 million by ramping up other facilities around September 25th. The facility will take more time to catch up to original capacity after the attacks. Current production is 750k barrels (50%).
Additional reports at full capacity.  Trusting for now...

Since, Saudi Aramco's (SA) oil production facilities have been attacked in the past, I find it credible that SA now has contingency plans and is able to quickly get production back up again. Since unprocessed oil is not in short supply in Saudi Arabia, I envisage an attempt by SA to "catch up" to its yearly target range.

Saud Geological formations are weak and fluctuation in production rates can "Pulse" a pool leading to multiple if small production disruption as they restart. On the other hand - they will report robust numbers as they prepare to offer ARAMCO in an IPO.

Capacity at two attached facilities have been mostly but not fully restored. Most reports seem to suggest that capacity is about 0.8 MBD below the previous levels. The Kingdom has been depleting its stocks to supply its customers. I do not consider stocks as "production."

Updating after having thought about the inventory aspect for a bit: Crude oil inventory of Saudi Arabia before the attacks was estimated at 180 million barrels[1]. 
I estimate that Saudi Arabia will use between 60M (best case) and 140M barrels (worst-case) to compensate for the lost production during the repairs. If production is at 9.9 tb/d now, it would take 30 days to replenish inventory if SA ran (and is in fact able to run) at 20% overproduction to achieve this goal. 
Because I expect an effort to replenish inventory and because the highest bucket is only 1% above the current official production, I am moving up to give the highest bucket the highest probability.  Crowd 2,5,17,73,3 [1] https://www.eia.gov/todayinenergy/detail.php?id=41413

https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-09-30/aramco-fully-restores-crude-output-as-it-recovers-from-attacks One key uncertainty that remains: will SA produce above demand to replenisch reserve and will this push average production into the top bucket?
Upgrading based on third party claim currently at 9.9 mb/d.
Upgrading on reports of reaching 8,000 tb/d. Cease fire in effect.

There are reports that production is back to normal. This seems very fast and might be a move to prevent spooking the market. Going to move up slightly until there is more supporting evidence of restored production.
https://mobile.reuters.com/article/amp/idUSKBN1WA0WN

The oil production in 2019 has seen around 75% oil production  between 9,000-10,000 tb/d with around 25% oil production more than 10,000 tb/d. The latest news that the Saudi minister stating that the 50% of the production cut by the attack has been restored, with that being stated I have kept around 5-6% margin spread between the last 3 possible answers, with the lesser of the bottom 3 being far less.

Regular production seems to be a little under 10,000 tb/d. The Saudis are claiming they will have production back to normal by the end of September. That seems unlikely but possible, certainly going to be watching the news about this closely since I feel like this answer could change quickly if they get delayed. That said, if they do get things back to normal this month, I suspect they will overproduce a bit to rebuild reserves and as a show of strength.
Upgrading based on news today that they are 6.2 delivery now with claimed capacity to 11.

Not surprisingly, public statements make this out to not be a big problem, and that production will be restored to normal by the end of September [1]. 
"Energy Minister Prince Abdulaziz bin Salman said on Tuesday that average oil production in September and October would be 9.89 million barrels per day" [1] There are conflicting statements by "sources briefed on developments", putting full restoration of production capacity between 2-3 weeks and "months" [2]. It seems that for a few weeks, shipments can be fulfilled by reserves [3,4] - not sure whether this will count as "production" for the OPEC report, though.  For my forecast, I am using a simple model with the following assumptions:
1) at the end of the repair process, production will have returned to the May-August 2019 average production (9762 tb/d)
2) from today until 2 weeks before full production is restored, the production will be at 6848 tb/d (this is based on the quote in [1] which states that more than half of lost production is already recovered - I am keeping it conservative at 50% recovery because I believe that publicly the progress will be overstated)
3) in the week before full production is restored, production will be half way between 2) and 1), that's 8305 tb/d, to account for some ramp up time. I then look at different scenarios based on the sources [1] and [2] that contain estimates on how long repairs will take, and assign the scenarios a probability. "2-3 weeks" is a current estimate being mentioned, I include 4 and 6 weeks for repairs to be completed due to a project management heuristic that most projects take between the estimated time and twice the estimated time. Scenario, average production, probability
Taking 2 weeks from 2019-09-17 to complete repairs, 9470 tb/d, 15%
Taking 3 weeks from 2019-09-17 to complete repairs, 8888 tb/d, 30%
Taking 4 weeks from 2019-09-17 to complete repairs, 8305 tb/d, 30%
Taking 6 weeks from 2019-09-17 to complete repairs, 7139 tb/d, 15%
Taking more than 6 weeks to complete repairs, 6848 tb/d, 10% Adding up the scenario probabilities for the corresponding buckets gets me to  10,15,60,15,0 Hedging a into the higher buckets because I think that if repairs go well, SA will run production above demand in order to replenish reserves. Crowd: 2,12,31,54,1 [1] https://www.reuters.com/article/us-saudi-aramco-energy-production/saudi-arabia-to-restore-oil-output-fully-by-end-of-september-energy-minister-idUSKBN1W2291
[2] https://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-saudi-aramco-oil-output-exclusive/exclusive-saudi-oil-output-to-return-faster-than-first-thought-sources-idUKKBN1W21O5
[3] https://seekingalpha.com/article/4292127-saudi-aramcos-oil-production-recovery-timetable
[4] https://www.eia.gov/todayinenergy/detail.php?id=41413

- Conflicting statements made by the Saudis and outside observers as to when production will be at full capacity again (end of Sep vs. months) 
- Without knowing the damage to each of the strike sites, I am going to guess a ramp of production that will take (guesstimate) three months to complete
- They are at about 4.3 tb/d (claim) today
- My guesstimate ramp would get them to 6.2 tb/d the final week of OCT or 5.70 tb/d average across the month of OCT

Saudi Arabia will shoot for producing to full capacity for two reasons. First, obviously it is their source of money and they don't want to lose any of it because of drone attack. Second, most importantly that they want to show world that attack have not deterred their stronghold and they can come back quickly and easily to fullest capacity.  Still, since their usual volume was in mid 9K barrels per day in July, they are likely to reach close to that value but probably not crossing 9K barrier.  They may fall short by 10-15% because of not full restoration and may attempt to  go for opening new sources to reach or exceed lost volume by a little margin.

Average monthly production 2002 - 2019 9,431 tb/d.
Max 11,021 tbpd
Min 7,121 tbpd
Target output 9,800 tbpd
September estimates at 8,000 tb/d - attack was on the 14th of Sept, so almost 50% of production target would have been achieved prior to attack. That indicates a 37% reduction in production capacity. Saudi has claimed a 58% reduction in production capacity. Saudi claims that repairs will be completed by the end of September and a normal output achieved in October. Other parties claim full production capacity won't be achieved until the end of the year. Likelihood of another similar attack before the end of October is low. https://www.businesstimes.com.sg/energy-commodities/saudi-oil-attack-where-are-we-a-week-on-and-what-happens-next

There will not be an OPEC meeting until December 2019, so this question is about the impact of the Iranian strikes on Saudi oil production to date, and the potential disruptions to supply in the next 6 weeks.  The US is reinforcing its radar defences, and the KSA will undoubtably reorientate and reorganise its defences. The base rate for attacks on oil production is still low, even if we have had two this year (one in august). Production was initially cut by 5.4 million barrels a day, but this was by closing the whole of the Abqaiq. The Saudis say that production will be back to normal by the end of September. Given the necessity of oil production for the saudi economy, this is likely to be a priority to restore the production. I will update if we get delays, but it seems the damage was worse at first sight than it turned out to be.

Saudi energy minister says oil output to be fully restored by end of the month Radwan (2019) September 18, stated that: JEDDAH: Saudi Arabia said Tuesday its oil output will return to normal by the end of September, seeking to soothe rattled energy markets after attacks on two instillations that slashed its production by half (Para.1). The Kingdom will achieve 11 million barrels per day (bpd) capacity by the end of September and 12 million bpd by the end of November, Prince Abdulaziz (Para. 9). Oil production in October would be 9.89 million bpd and the world’s top oil exporter would keep full oil supplies to customers this month, he said. “We don’t know who is behind the attack,” Prince Abdulaziz said, adding that the kingdom wants “proof based on professionalism and internationally recognised standards” (Para. 9-11). Radwan, R. (2019). Saudi energy minister says oil output to be fully restored by end of the month. Arab News. September 18, 2019. Retrieved from
https://www.arabnews.com/node/1556161/saudi-arabia
absent a coherent response, Iran is going to continue to attempt to interfere with oil shipments through the gulf.
